content.question: Based on the diagrams shown above, which of the following would have the greatest dipole moment, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="C S 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the double bonds create an area of higher electron density around the <math alttext="C atom" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>t</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="P C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the <math alttext="C l atoms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>t</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></math> draw electron density away from the <math alttext="P atom" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>t</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></math> and the bond dipoles do not cancel one another.

<math alttext="S F 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it has the greatest number of polar bonds.

<math alttext="C F 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the large electronegativity difference between <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> results in very polar bonds.

content.answer: <math alttext="P C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the <math alttext="C l atoms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>t</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></math> draw electron density away from the <math alttext="P atom" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>t</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></math> and the bond dipoles do not cancel one another.

skill.text: 6.C: Support a claim with evidence from representations or models at the particulate level, such as the structure of atoms and/or molecules.
